resources.string: Ibuprofen syrup or suspension (dose 100 mg in 5 ml)
Paracetamol syrup or suspension (dose 120 mg in 5 ml)
30 minutes to 6 hours after iron ingestion
Reduction and improvement of gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhea
It is better to use paracetamol drops.
At this weight, it is better to use paracetamol.
You can use a paracetamol suppository.
Use paracetamol drops and consult a doctor.
‚ö†Ô∏è If your baby is less than 10 days old, consult a pharmacist or doctor.

‚ö†Ô∏è If using multiple medications at the same time, consult a pharmacist or doctor to determine the correct dose. Example 1: Simultaneous use of paracetamol syrup and suppository. Example 2: Simultaneous use of ibuprofen syrup and suppository. Example 3: Use of combination drugs like Coryzan and paracetamol syrup and suppository.
‚ö†Ô∏è Make sure your child is not allergic to the medications; consult a doctor or pharmacist for more information.
Avoid using ibuprofen syrup on an empty stomach.
Use one 75 mg suppository every 6 hours (if fever persists).
Use one 75 mg suppository. If fever persists, you can use up to 5 suppositories in 24 hours.
Use one 125 mg suppository. If needed, up to 5 suppositories in 24 hours every 4 to 6 hours.
Use one 325 mg suppository depending on fever or pain level, up to 5 suppositories in 24 hours.
Age must be entered as an integer.
Cow milk allergy must be specified.

You must select one of the options.

Use 1 suppository 75 mg, up to 3 in 24 hours if symptoms persist (fever).
Use 1 suppository 75 mg, up to 4 in 24 hours if symptoms persist (fever).
Use 1 suppository 150 mg, up to 3 in 24 hours if symptoms persist (fever).
Use 1 suppository 150 mg, up to 4 in 24 hours if symptoms persist (fever).
Use paracetamol drops or consult a doctor.
Use paracetamol drops or consult a doctor.
It is better to use paracetamol syrup.
At least one of "weight" or "age" must be entered.
If symptoms like fever persist, take the appropriate dose every 4 to 6 hours, maximum 5 doses in 24 hours.
If symptoms like fever persist, take the appropriate dose every 6 to 8 hours.
‚ö†Ô∏è For children under 5 kg, consult a pharmacist or doctor.
‚ö†Ô∏è If using medication to reduce fever, read the fever evaluation section in the app.
Use every 6 to 8 hours according to child‚Äôs fever.
Please enter the child‚Äôs age or weight.
The dosage calculator calculates the exact dose of various drugs based on the child‚Äôs age and weight and standard medical formulas.
‚ö†Ô∏è This tool is only a guide and does not replace consultation with a doctor or pharmacist.
For more accuracy, enter the weight. If you don‚Äôt have it, enter the age.
Your smart companion for your child‚Äôs health care
With KooDoc, you always know when to see a doctor, which symptoms matter, and how to better care for your child.
To help you better, I need some information.
Let me ask you a few questions, okay?
Are you the child‚Äôs primary caregiver?
Tell me a bit about your baby, I‚Äôd love to know more! üòä
Which of the following conditions does the child have?
Formula suitable for the child‚Äôs allergy
Does the child go to school or kindergarten?
Vaccination of children with special conditions
Mild illnesses with or without fever (such as mild respiratory infection, mild diarrhea) or recent use of antibiotics are not barriers to vaccination‚Ä¶
Does not interfere with receiving vaccines.

If the baby is steadily gaining weight and is not affected by specific illnesses such as acute kidney, brain, or respiratory diseases, they can receive vaccines like other children. \nIt is recommended that parents and close contacts of premature babies get the flu vaccine in September.
Children with seizures and brain lesions

If the child has neurological disorders such as uncontrolled seizures (seizures occurring in the last 3 months despite taking anticonvulsant drugs), epilepsy (including infantile spasms), progressive brain diseases, or a history of seizures that have not been fully evaluated, vaccination with pertussis-containing vaccines should be postponed until the neurological disorder is fully assessed, appropriate treatment has started, and the child\'s condition has stabilized.
Physical methods to calm the child

Skin-to-skin contact between mother and baby
Administering the vaccine while the child is in the parent's arms
Caressing the child
Feeding the child with fluids and breast milk
If multiple vaccines need to be given at one visit, it is recommended to give oral vaccines first and the most painful injection last.
Psychological methods to calm the child

Calm, soothe, and comfort the baby during and after vaccination
Distract the child using toys, reading stories, or playing their favorite music
Avoid using words that cause anxiety when talking to the child
Avoid giving excessive reassurance to the child

Following vaccination, reactions such as fever, pain, swelling at the injection site, and child restlessness are common. Being aware of this can ease your worries.
If swelling and redness occur at the injection site, applying a clean, cold, moist cloth can help reduce pain.
Pain, fever, and local reactions after vaccination: it is recommended to use antipyretic and pain-relieving medication but **not before vaccination** as it is ineffective and may reduce vaccine efficacy. After vaccination, if fever, pain, and restlessness occur, use paracetamol or ibuprofen in the appropriate dose for the child's weight and age, as advised by a pharmacist or doctor.
Avoid tight clothing that puts pressure on the injection site.
Washing the injection site and bathing the child after vaccination has no benefit.
Tips to reduce discomfort, pain, and fever:

According to CDC guidelines, all children aged 11‚Äì12 should receive one dose of the meningococcal conjugate vaccine. Since immunity from this vaccine decreases over time, those vaccinated before age 16 need a booster dose at least 8 weeks later, preferably between ages 16‚Äì18. (CDC recommendation 2024)
The following conditions are not reasons to prohibit vaccination and do not require delaying immunization
Iron poisoning is a serious condition in children. If poisoning is suspected or symptoms appear, go to the poisoning emergency unit immediately.
Most important: even with a low suspicion of poisoning\ngo to the hospital emergency department immediately and be honest with the medical staff about the cause.

Some people may have severe allergic reactions to bee stings. If the child belongs to this group and has previously had a severe reaction to a bee sting, consult a doctor.\nIf this is the child‚Äôs first sting, go to a medical center.
Carefully inspect the sting site and remove the stinger without squeezing using a tool like a credit card to prevent more venom entering the body. Seek medical attention.
Every snake bite should be considered venomous. Even a child without symptoms must be taken to the emergency room.

Calm the bitten child.
Remove any tight items (watch, ring, clothing bands, socks, tight clothes).
Keep the bitten limb at heart level and immobilized.
Clean the bite site.
Even if no symptoms appear, take the child to a medical center.
Do not cut, suck out venom by mouth, apply ice, or use cold compresses.
If you see any of these signs, go to the emergency room immediately
If you see the signs below, go to a pharmacy or clinic
If you see the signs below, see a doctor within 24 hours
If you see the signs below, you can provide home care
